awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Solar and Heliospheric Physics at UAH and MSFC
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site is a joint effort by the University of Alabama in Huntsville (UAH) and the NASA Marshall Space Flight Center (MSFC) to promote diversity and retention in scientific fields related to solar and heliospheric physics. The synergy between these entities is facilitated by the colocation on the UAH campus of (i) the newly formed UAH Space Science department; (ii) the UAH Center for Space Plasma and Aeronomic Research (CSPAR); and (iii) the NASA MSFC Solar Physics group.  Each year 10 students will be selected and paired with scientists from either UAH or MSFC to work for 10 weeks over the summer on projects related to data analysis, instrumentation design and testing, simulations of plasma physics phenomena, or the development and implementation of theoretical and modeling techniques. Careful pairing of students skills with the requirements of the research projects, will allow acceptance of undergraduates across a wide range of experience levels, including those who have only completed their freshman year. A workshop is held during the first week of the program that includes lectures about the Sun and its interaction with the interstellar environment, and hands-on session that teach the basics of computer programming. 


The intellectual merit of this project centers on the research performed by students, which they present as a poster at the end of the summer program. In addition, each participant is encouraged to submit their work to a scientific session at the annual American Geophysical Union conference held each December. The program has funds to partially support students attending this conference. The broader impacts of the project relate to the retention of students in STEM fields and the participation of minorities in science. To meet these goals recruitment efforts are targeted towards colleges and universities in the South-Eastern United States whose level of research activity is comparatively low or are minority serving institutions.  Evaluation of applicants will include a ?need? factor in addition to more traditional assessments of academic preparation. This additional factor enables a keen student from a low research institution, who may have little or no understanding research experience, to compete acceptance into this REU with students from more research intensive schools. This program will aim to select a cohort of students each summer with a range of experience levels so that participants may learn research skills from peers in addition to their mentors.

por.por_cntn:
This Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site was a joint effort by the University of Alabama in Huntsville (UAH) and the NASA Marshall Space Flight Center (MSFC) to promote diversity and retention in scientific fields related to solar and heliospheric physics. The synergy between these entities is facilitated by the colocation on the UAH campus of (i) the UAH Department of Space Science; (ii) the UAH Center for Space Plasma and Aeronomic Research (CSPAR); and (iii) the NASA MSFC Solar Physics group. During the period of performance of this award, each year 10 students were selected and paired with scientists from either UAH or MSFC to work for 10 weeks over the summer on projects related to data analysis, instrumentation design and testing, simulations of plasma physics phenomena, or the development and implementation of theoretical and modeling techniques. Careful pairing of students? skills with the requirements of the research projects allowed acceptance of undergraduates across a wide range of experience levels including those who had only completed their freshman year. During the REU program, students were provided science lectures by UAH and MSFC scientists on various subjects related to solar and heliospheric physics. They were also given hands-on tutorial sessions that taught the basics of computer programming at the beginning of the REU program. These two aspects of the program provided the students with the necessary training and skills to enable them to work on their research projects. Apart from these training activities, students were given the opportunity to participate in professional development sessions, which the UAH Summer Community of Scholars offers to all participants of the undergraduate-level summer internship programs at UAH. These sessions gave the students information about diverse topics such as research ethics, information literacy, preparing for graduate school, prestigious scholarships and fellowships, and creating an effective project poster.

 

The intellectual merit of this project centered on the research performed by students, the results of which they presented as a poster at the end of the summer program. In addition, each participant submitted his/her work as a first author abstract to a scientific session at the annual American Geophysical Union conference held each December or to the American Astronomical Society meeting. Each participant was encouraged to attend one of these meetings in person under a partial travel support funded by this award. In addition to presentations of their research at well-known conferences in the field, REU students sometimes continued their research work after the REU program ended with intention to publish a journal article about their research. Five of our REU students were co-authors on refereed journal publications during the period of performance of this project. The broader impacts of the project were related to the retention of students in STEM fields and the participation of minorities in science. To meet these goals, recruitment efforts were targeted towards colleges and universities in the South-Eastern United States whose level of research activity was comparatively low or that were minority serving institutions. In addition, applications received from all around the nation were carefully evaluated by taking the target recruitment goals of this project into account. Evaluation of applicants included a ?need? factor in addition to more traditional assessments of academic preparation. This additional factor enabled a keen student from a low research level institution, who may have little or no understanding of research experience, to be competitive with students from more research intensive school for acceptance into the REU programs. This program aimed to select a cohort of students each summer with a range of experience levels so that participants might learn research skills from peers in addition to their mentors.

 

The AGS-1460767 grant was successful in meeting our recruitment goals. We achieved minority participation levels of between 30% and 40%. Over the last two years, we achieved parity in men and women participation (50%). Furthermore, over the past 5 years, 36% of the participants did not originate from a research university environment. We began to develop more comprehensive survey tools that showed that participants completed the camp possessing a clearer perspective of future opportunities in graduate STEM education and a desire to explore these options. Our longitudinal tracking found that 14 REU students (2014-19) went on to graduate school (to 13 different schools, including 2 who attend(ed) UAH), 12 more completed their graduate degrees and entered the workforce and 7 did not graduate (based on 33 out of 52 respondents).
